image.altText: Australian canoeist Jessica Fox during the Women's Kayak Single heats at the Paris Olympics, finsihing her run

props.synopsis: Jess Fox has booked herself a spot in the canoe slalom K1 final, as Chloe Covell competes in the skateboarding street final. Follow live.

title.children: Jess Fox books spot in canoe slalom K1 final, skateboarder Chloe Covell to compete for gold

image.altText: Anthony Albanese press conference

props.synopsis: The prime minister has unveiled his new-look frontbench as he seeks to refresh his cabinet ahead of the next federal election.

title.children: Anthony Albanese moves Clare O'Neil, Andrew Giles in cabinet reshuflle

image.altText: A graphic shows several ministers and a deck of cards being sorted.

props.synopsis: Promotions, demotions and retirements — find out who is entering cabinet or picking up a ministry out of the Albanese government's reshuffle.

title.children: Who's in and who's out after Anthony Albanese's ministry reshuffle?

image.altText: A woman looking up and smiling.

props.synopsis: Senator McCarthy has been announced as the new minister for Indigenous Australians. Her rise to one of Australia's most challenging and prestigious positions didn't come without hardship and hurdles on the way.

title.children: The rise of Malarndirri McCarthy to one of Australia’s most important roles

image.altText: Isaac Heeney shows his frustration

props.synopsis: Major questions have been raised surrounding Sydney's premiership credentials after the Swans were manhandled by the Western Bulldogs at the SCG on Sunday.

title.children: 'A long way off': Major questions raised over Sydney's premiership credentials after SCG meltdown against Bulldogs

image.altText: Woman in wide-brim hat smiles in front of large rock

props.synopsis: Despite battling pain, exhaustion and disorientation, Liz Woodgate, 60, completed the 460 kilometre journey.

title.children: Most people take two weeks to hike the Larapinta Trail. Liz ran it twice in six days

image.altText: Australian swimmers Shayna Jack, Mollie O’Callaghan, Emma McKeon and Meg Harris pose with their gold medals

props.synopsis: Medals are being handed out on day two of the 024 Paris Olympic Games, but none for the Aussies yet. Check out the full medal tally.

title.children: Here's the medal standings for Day Two of the Olympic Games

image.altText: A surfer rides a wave in front of homes beneath a lighthouse

props.synopsis: Cafe owner Phil Taylor spent 20 years in Byron Bay for its surf and vibrant lifestyle, but he's recently chosen to move closer to the city for a fraction of the price.

title.children: Byron Bay used to have a 'magic' about it — then sea changers steamrolled the locals

image.altText: A boat passes over the Seine river, with a Paris 2024 banner displayed across an arched bridge

props.synopsis: Poor water quality in the River Seine has forced a cancellation of swim training for Olympic triathletes.

title.children: Poor water quality in the River Seine sees triathlon training cancelled

image.altText: A tennis player wearing a white shirt and green hat hits a tennis ball.

props.synopsis: Alex de Minaur withdraws from his Olympic singles first round clash with German Jan-Lennard Struff, opting to focus on doubles as he manages a hip injury.

title.children: De Minaur out of men's tennis singles at Paris Games due to Wimbledon hip injury

image.altText: Hockeyroos players celebrate in a group

props.synopsis: Despite lingering questions over selections, the Hockeyroos are letting their play do the talking, showing plenty of grit to come from 1-0 down and start their Olympic Games campaign with a win.

title.children: Time for talk is over as Hockeyroos claim opening Games win

image.altText: A mudslide tears through a green forest of trees before destroying a house at the base of a hill

props.synopsis: The people were killed in a mudslide in a tourist region of China that had been battered by significant rainfall linked to the typhoon, which had been downgraded to a tropical storm after passing through Taiwan.

title.children: Fifteen killed in China as fallout from Typhoon Gaemi continues

image.altText: A woman wearing yellow Tshirt holds up a poster of a man's face with MISSING PERSON text on top

props.synopsis: Tensions are building in remote northern Australia after a string of mysterious disappearances. It comes as an increasing number of Australians are reported missing.

title.children: One by one, young men disappear. This is the story of the Lockyer men, and why more Australians are going missing

image.altText: Crowds of people dressed in black and red are seen from above carrying several white-covered funeral caskets

props.synopsis: The Israeli military says a series of targets were attacked both "deep inside Lebanese territory and in southern Lebanon", after a rocket strike on Golan Heights that Israel blames on Hezbollah.

title.children: Israel attacks Hezbollah targets after strike on Golan Heights

image.altText: Thousands of people have attended rallies against gendered violence across the country this weekend

props.synopsis: Survivors of gendered violence and families of loved ones killed in horrific acts were among those campaigning for change across the country this weekend. Here's what they want to happen next.

title.children: What survivors of abuse say must happen to put an end to gender-based violence for good

image.altText: Dean Boxall

props.synopsis: In an exclusive insight, Dean Boxall explains the secrets within a model Eiffel Tower in Brisbane, that has helped Australia's golden start in the pool.

title.children: Inside a model of the Eiffel Tower in Brisbane lies a secret helping Australia's golden start in Paris

image.altText: A close up portrait of Miranda July who has curled auburn hair and blue eyes and is standing against a tiled wall

props.synopsis: Could it be true that midlife crises are worthy, necessary expeditions and not simply cringey, cliched self-indulgence? The central character in Miranda July's new book, All Fours, thinks so.

title.children: Midlife crises aren't all balding men in flash cars. For women, midlife can be psychedelic

image.altText: A road with palm trees along the side, and blue sky.

props.synopsis: Pacific Island nations are spending big to repay loans from China. But some say there are other roads available to them if they want to overcome their debt burdens.

title.children: China has loaned Pacific Island nations money for infrastructure — the debts have become 'astronomical'

image.altText: Aami Mills

props.synopsis: Queanbeyan-based business owner Aami Mills lost $10,000 to hackers after creating her own small business and using social media to advertise. Now, she's taking extra steps to protect herself, but says social media companies should do more.

title.children: Hackers posted malicious advertising on Aami's Facebook business account costing her $10,000 in four hours

image.altText: A collage of three apartments over a graphic of the skyline with a balcony visible

props.synopsis: From tenants kicked out after decades, to no one ever moving in, these three apartment sites in Sydney help paint a picture of "inactive" or unoccupied housing across Australia.

title.children: The apartment towers with no residents looming over Sydney neighbourhoods

image.altText: People stand with placards at a rally against gender-based violence on a wintery day

props.synopsis: For the first time since her mother's murder, Romany Wake shares her story, telling a rally calling for an end to domestic and family violence her family was "let down" by the justice system.

title.children: Murder victim was ‘not believed’ when she tried to raise concerns, daughter tells rally

image.altText: Assistant Commissioner Brett McFadden, Commander, South West Metropolitan Region addresses the media

props.synopsis: Police say five officers arrived at the scene on Saturday night in two police cars where they were confronted and threatened by the 34-year-old man.

title.children: Man shot dead by police in Sydney's south-west after officer allegedly attacked with knife

image.altText: A young man shows a can to a police officer in a helmet

props.synopsis: Before there was violent protest, the National Guard and a pig nominated for office — in August 1968, the Democratic National Convention was facing the same dilemma we are now.

title.children: The last time a president decided not to run for re-election, the streets of Chicago descended into chaos

image.altText: Young girl with black hair wearing activewear smiles standing in front of a tree with expanse of mountains behind her.

props.synopsis: With some parents struggling to manage their young people's use of smartphones and social media, others are taking a firm position against "addictive" technology to protect teenagers' mental health.

title.children: When this teen's parents denied her a smartphone she was initially distraught. Now she says it was the best decision

image.altText: Man in grey-blue suit, without tie stands in front of a camera reporting. He is outside the White House in Washington DC.

props.synopsis: An election campaign that was mostly static before the presidential debate has transformed into one of the most volatile and consequential in more than 50 years.

title.children: I went to Washington to tap into US politics, but got much more than I bargained for

image.altText: Christine Anu from shoulders up, wearing a crown of colourful flowers on her head.

props.synopsis: ARIA-award winning music icon Christine Anu will this week release a new album. She explains why the time is now for Waku – Minaral A Minalay and the inspiration behind it.

title.children: Christine Anu explores her roots on new album, Waku – Minaral A Minalay

image.altText: A mother and daughter walking arm in arm along a country river on a rainy day.

props.synopsis: Sue Macgregor thought her daughter was crazy when she suggested they buy a takeaway shop in the country to help manage Sue's dementia.

title.children: How buying a takeaway shop helped this mother and daughter get beyond dementia diagnosis

image.altText: Two women sit on grass smiling at each other, while one holds a small child.

props.synopsis: A growing number of Australian women are opting to bypass traditional fertility clinics and instead turning to unregulated Facebook groups in search of sperm donors — a practice experts say is fraught with safety risks and moral quandaries.

title.children: A couple posted to Facebook looking for a sperm donor. Two days later they were sitting across from him

image.altText: A young woman.

props.synopsis: Jamie Leonard weighed 35 kilograms and felt like there was cement in her chest when she was misdiagnosed with an eating disorder. In reality, she had a rare swallowing disorder and says she wasn't being listened to by doctors.

title.children: Jamie was wrongly diagnosed with an eating disorder. She says specialists weren't listening to her

image.altText: A man sits at a weight lifting bench inside a gym

props.synopsis: Gus Cooke took illegal anabolic steroids for more than a decade and he doesn't recommend their use. A new drug-checking trial aims to minimise harm among steroid users.

title.children: This powerlifting coach has taken performance-enhancing drugs for most of his adult life. He doesn't recommend it

image.altText: Tom Gleeson standing with his arms crossed and a serious look on his face. The Hard Quiz has been added behind his head

props.synopsis: I s'pose you think you're a bit alright at this trivia thing. Go ahead — try and impress me.

title.children: Are you a trivia expert? Let's play … HARD!

image.altText: Mirror balls at the Laruche Nightclub at Fortitude Valley in Brisbane's CBD.

props.synopsis: Police allege a man assaulted a man and woman in their 60s, damaged a statue and spat on an officer.

title.children: Man charged after three injured in fracas outside swingers club south of Brisbane

image.altText: Thai royals wearing formal military uniforms walk near minders in shade in an open space outside.

props.synopsis: Thailand has the strictest lèse-majesté, or royal defamation, laws in the world and right now, they're threatening to bring down the opposition and a former prime minister.

title.children: Why Thais continue fighting the world's strictest royal defamation laws
